name: Haichao Wei
title: Research Engineer - GAI

patents.title: Internet of things structured query language query formation
patents.description: In an example, one or more tokens in a freeform search query are identified, each token corresponding to a search term or combination of neighboring search terms in the freeform search query. A graph structure and flat data corresponding to the graph structure are obtained. A search for results relevant to the identified one or more tokens is performed using a first search process, the first search process using the graph structure and flat data to rank search results according to a first ranking order and populate a why found table Pieces of data corresponding to the results relevant to the identified one or more tokens are joined using the why found table, forming a view and one or more patterns of operators and terms, in a pattern database, matching the one or more operators and one or more surrounding terms in the freeform search query are found. Show less

patents.title: Internet of things search and discovery
patents.description: In an example, data in a non-flat format and metadata corresponding to the data are obtained from a first database. The data is flattened into flat data and augmented with the metadata. One or more pieces of the flat data are scanned to locate a first piece of flat data having a first attribute with attribute values that are a subset of attribute values of a second attribute of a second piece of flat data. A link is then created between the first attribute of the first piece of flat data and the second attribute of the second piece of flat data. A graph structure is generated, the graph structure containing a plurality of nodes, each node corresponding to a data type of the flat data and corresponding to one or more pieces of data in the flat data of the corresponding data type. Show less

patents.title: DIGITAL ASSISTANT QUERY INTENT RECOMMENDATION GENERATION
patents.description: Systems and methods are provided for digital assistant configuration and functionality. For example, systems and methods provide for receiving a query from a user via a computing device, processing language in the query to identify a plurality of elements associated with the query, and analyzing the plurality of elements associated with the query to determine an intent of the query by mapping the plurality of elements associated with the query to a list of predetermined intents by comparing the plurality of elements associated with the query to each intent in the list of predetermined intents to generate a score for each intent in the list of predetermined intents. Systems and methods further provide for determining a subset of the predetermined intents based on the score for each intent in the list of predetermined intents, and providing recommendations related to the query based on the subset of predetermined intents. Show less

patents.title: Business scope dependent add-on content provisioning
patents.description: A system and method to install a software enhancement supplement of a main software product, the method including receiving an installation recommendation for the supplement having content including a business configuration (BC) object on a customer/service provider side of a business process platform from a product provider; displaying an indication of the receipt of the installation recommendation; processing the installation of the supplement into the business process platform of the customer; and providing a notification of the supplement's status upon completion of the supplement installation. Show less

patents.title: Generic database manipulator
patents.description: A middle layer in business applications is provided to wrap all the database management operations generically, to store changed data temporarily, to validate and lock the data before updating the database, and to synchronize the data change and unlock it as a whole when a commit method is called. In embodiments, only six generic methods are needed for all data interactions. Transaction, isolation level, exception format, and performance tuning operations can be performed centrally in the six generic methods. A buffer section may be created in the middle layer. Operations such as insert, update, delete, and select are performed on data stored in the buffer. Buffered data may then be stored in a data storage device. Show less

recommendations.recommendation:
“Since June 2019, I had the honor of working with Haichao on the same team.
He has been acting as my mentor in terms of NLP and machine learning. I learned a lot from him.
One of the most impressive things about Haichao is his drive to be always on the cutting-edge of the industry.
In addition to his superb technical skills, Haichao is one of the most compassionate people I have ever worked with.  He genuinely cares for the well-being of people around him and maintains calm and smile.
I find myself blessed to be able to work in an environment where I can enjoy true friendship thanks to Haichao.”

name: Jeffrey Hui
title: Research Engineer, Google DeepMind
location: New York, New York, United States

publications.title: PaLM 2 Technical Report
publications.description: We introduce PaLM 2, a new state-of-the-art language model that has better multilingual and reasoning capabilities and is more compute-efficient than its predecessor PaLM. PaLM 2 is a Transformer-based model trained using a mixture of objectives. Through extensive evaluations on English and multilingual language, and reasoning tasks, we demonstrate that PaLM 2 has significantly improved quality on downstream tasks across different model sizes, while simultaneously exhibiting faster and more efficient inference compared to PaLM. This improved efficiency enables broader deployment while also allowing the model to respond faster, for a more natural pace of interaction. PaLM 2 demonstrates robust reasoning capabilities exemplified by large improvements over PaLM on BIG-Bench and other reasoning tasks. PaLM 2 exhibits stable performance on a suite of responsible AI evaluations, and enables inference-time control over toxicity without additional overhead or impact on other capabilities. Overall, PaLM 2 achieves state-of-the-art performance across a diverse set of tasks and capabilities. When discussing the PaLM 2 family, it is important to distinguish between pre-trained models (of various sizes), fine-tuned variants of these models, and the user-facing products that use these models. In particular, user-facing products typically include additional pre- and post-processing steps. Additionally, the underlying models may evolve over time. Therefore, one should not expect the performance of user-facing products to exactly match the results reported in this report. Show less

publications.title: No News is Good News: A Critique of the One Billion Word Benchmark
publications.description: The One Billion Word Benchmark is a dataset derived from the WMT 2011 News Crawl, commonly used to measure language modeling ability in natural language processing. We train models solely on Common Crawl web scrapes partitioned by year, and demonstrate that they perform worse on this task over time due to distributional shift. Analysis of this corpus reveals that it contains several examples of harmful text, as well as outdated references to current events. We suggest that the temporal nature of news and its distribution shift over time makes it poorly suited for measuring language modeling ability, and discuss potential impact and considerations for researchers building language models and evaluation datasets. Show less

First I learned how to design, implement, and deploy planet-scale software systems. The beauty and power of the Web made my eyes shine. - Built server-side of internet-banking system for moskb.ru (Python, Django); - Helped to build financial processing center as a member of activepay.ru server-side team (Python, Django, RabbitMQ); - Build server-side of maps.westernunion.ru as a member of ksan.ru team (Python, Django, GeoDjango). Show less

I was offered the CEO position at a start-up “Russian Widgets” that almost got seed funding. This start-up worked with many bright engineers, working their day jobs and spending an hour or two in the evenings to discuss the new startup’s product. I invested my own money to start full-time work on the product, but our potential investor declined the opportunity. We started to brainstorm for new product ideas; one of them was “Instant messaging with pictures”. Nobody believed in it at the start, but I implemented a working prototype in two weeks, and our first users loved it! I persuaded the engineering team to join this project. We built an alpha version, which helped to raise seed investments. Our investor stopped funding just before a beta launch (winter 2008-2009 was unusually cold for startups). We released international (moodbox.com) and russian (risovaska.ru) versions of our product, but had no resources to continue its development. Show less

While being an IC, I was very active in improving our processes. I was offered the TLM position to implement a lot of ideas that I often proposed to my managers. I hired best people in the area and tried hard to remove any obstacles from their paths. Our team’s work was highly successful. I got the “Employee of the Year” award. Members of that team now work at Google, Groupon, and other promising start-ups.

current_description: Working on Gemini Long Context, DeepThink and Post-Training Research. Student Researcher turned Research Engineer.

experience_summary.description: Working on Gemini Long Context, DeepThink and Post-Training Research. Student Researcher turned Research Engineer.

Researching improving factuality in Large Language Models using Retrieval Augmentation and reducing hallucinations under Prof. Chris Manning. Developed RAPTOR, a novel tree-based retrieval augmentation technique, that is able to leverage large-scale discourse in documents outperforming traditional retrieval techniques and setting the state-of-the-art on 3 datasets. (ICLR '24)

Research Assistant at SNAP lab with Prof. Jure Leskovec. Co-first author of Optimas: Optimizing Compound AI Systems with Globally Aligned Local Rewards.
Research Internship on retrieval augmented language modeling, grounding language models quantitatively.

name: Neel Choudhury
title: Research Engineer @ Google Deepmind | Ex - IISc

publications.title: Analysis of Subgraph -centric Distributed Shortest Path  Algorithm
publications.description: Abstract—Path-based graph algorithms are key building blocks for several link prediction and spatial mining applications. As the sizes of social, transport and communication networks expand, performing scalable traversal algorithms like SSSP are critical. While there is heightened interest in vertex-centric platforms for scalable graph analysis, there is limited literature on understanding the behavior of distributed algorithms designed using them. Consequently, it is often difficult to offer a tight bound on their algorithm’s complexity. Here, using SSSP as a canonical algorithm on a subgraph-centric abstraction, we perform an algorithmic analysis of its characteristics using meta- graph sketches. We then analyze its empirical performance using real-world graphs to correlate the expected and observed outcomes. Our analysis shows that the runtime behavior of the SSSP algorithm meets the expected behavior, and confirms the bounds on the number of times Dijkstra’s is performed, based on the traversal visit of the meta-graph. Show less

publications.title: Distributed Programming over Time-Series Graphs
publications.description: Graphs are a key form of Big Data, and performing scalable analytics over them is invaluable to many domains. There is an emerging class of inter-connected data which accumulates or varies over time, and on which novel algorithms both over the network structure and across the time-variant attribute values is necessary. We formalize the notion of time-series graphs and propose a Temporally Iterative BSP programming abstraction to develop algorithms on such datasets using several design patterns. Our abstractions leverage a sub-graph centric programming model and extend it to the temporal dimension. We present three time-series graph algorithms based on these design patterns and abstractions, and analyze their performance using the Offish distributed platform on Amazon AWS Cloud. Our results demonstrate the efficacy of the abstractions to develop practical time-series graph algorithms, and scale them on commodity hardware. Show less

publications.title: Verifiable Secret Sharing Scheme on Images using Watermarking
publications.description: We have implemented Adi Shamir’s (k, n) threshold secret sharing scheme onto 24-bit bitmap images. Along with this we have used a concept of watermarking, hash function and a multilayered threshold secret sharing approach to verify the authenticity of each image share before processing instead of decrypting blindly. Moreover this verification scheme allows us to identify dishonest participants who might have gained unauthorized access on secret shares. Consequently, this proposed scheme offers a highly secure mechanism of image secret sharing, which is different from existing traditional methods. Although we have implemented this scheme on images it can easily be used on any digital format as we are dealing with streams of bits Show less

publications.title: Analysis of Subgraph -centric Distributed Shortest Path  Algorithm
publications.description: Abstract—Path-based graph algorithms are key building blocks for several link prediction and spatial mining applications. As the sizes of social, transport and communication networks expand, performing scalable traversal algorithms like SSSP are critical. While there is heightened interest in vertex-centric platforms for scalable graph analysis, there is limited literature on understanding the behavior of distributed algorithms designed using them. Consequently, it is often difficult to offer a tight bound on their algorithm’s complexity. Here, using SSSP as a canonical algorithm on a subgraph-centric abstraction, we perform an algorithmic analysis of its characteristics using meta- graph sketches. We then analyze its empirical performance using real-world graphs to correlate the expected and observed outcomes. Our analysis shows that the runtime behavior of the SSSP algorithm meets the expected behavior, and confirms the bounds on the number of times Dijkstra’s is performed, based on the traversal visit of the meta-graph. Show less

publications.title: Distributed Programming over Time-Series Graphs
publications.description: Graphs are a key form of Big Data, and performing scalable analytics over them is invaluable to many domains. There is an emerging class of inter-connected data which accumulates or varies over time, and on which novel algorithms both over the network structure and across the time-variant attribute values is necessary. We formalize the notion of time-series graphs and propose a Temporally Iterative BSP programming abstraction to develop algorithms on such datasets using several design patterns. Our abstractions leverage a sub-graph centric programming model and extend it to the temporal dimension. We present three time-series graph algorithms based on these design patterns and abstractions, and analyze their performance using the Offish distributed platform on Amazon AWS Cloud. Our results demonstrate the efficacy of the abstractions to develop practical time-series graph algorithms, and scale them on commodity hardware. Show less

publications.title: Verifiable Secret Sharing Scheme on Images using Watermarking
publications.description: We have implemented Adi Shamir’s (k, n) threshold secret sharing scheme onto 24-bit bitmap images. Along with this we have used a concept of watermarking, hash function and a multilayered threshold secret sharing approach to verify the authenticity of each image share before processing instead of decrypting blindly. Moreover this verification scheme allows us to identify dishonest participants who might have gained unauthorized access on secret shares. Consequently, this proposed scheme offers a highly secure mechanism of image secret sharing, which is different from existing traditional methods. Although we have implemented this scheme on images it can easily be used on any digital format as we are dealing with streams of bits Show less

publications.title: EmbeddingGemma: Powerful and Lightweight Text Representations
publications.description: We introduce EmbeddingGemma, a new lightweight, open text embedding model based on the Gemma 3 language model family. Our innovative training recipe strategically captures knowledge from larger models via encoder-decoder initialization and geometric embedding distillation. We improve model robustness and expressiveness with a spread-out regularizer, and ensure generalizability by merging checkpoints from varied, optimized mixtures. Evaluated on the Massive Text Embedding Benchmark (MTEB) across multilingual, English, and code domains, EmbeddingGemma (300M) achieves state-of-the-art results. Notably, it outperforms prior top models, both proprietary and open, with fewer than 500M parameters, and provides performance comparable to models double its size, offering an exceptional performance-to-cost ratio. Remarkably, this lead persists when quantizing model weights or truncating embedding outputs. This makes EmbeddingGemma particularly well-suited for low-latency and high-throughput use cases such as on-device applications. We provide ablation studies exploring our key design choices. We release EmbeddingGemma to the community to promote further research. Show less

publications.title: Entity Image and Mixed-Modal Image Retrieval Datasets
publications.description: Despite advances in multimodal learning, challenging benchmarks for mixed-modal image retrieval that combines visual and textual information are lacking. This paper introduces a novel benchmark to rigorously evaluate image retrieval that demands deep cross-modal contextual understanding. We present two new datasets: the Entity Image Dataset (EI), providing canonical images for Wikipedia entities, and the Mixed-Modal Image Retrieval Dataset (MMIR), derived from the WIT dataset. The MMIR benchmark features two challenging query types requiring models to ground textual descriptions in the context of provided visual entities: single entity-image queries (one entity image with descriptive text) and multi-entity-image queries (multiple entity images with relational text). We empirically validate the benchmark's utility as both a training corpus and an evaluation set for mixed-modal retrieval. The quality of both datasets is further affirmed through crowd-sourced human annotations. Show less

publications.title: Gemini Embedding: Generalizable Embeddings from Gemini
publications.description: In this report, we introduce Gemini Embedding, a state-of-the-art embedding model leveraging the power of Gemini, Google's most capable large language model. Capitalizing on Gemini's inherent multilingual and code understanding capabilities, Gemini Embedding produces highly generalizable embeddings for text spanning numerous languages and textual modalities. The representations generated by Gemini Embedding can be precomputed and applied to a variety of downstream tasks including classification, similarity, clustering, ranking, and retrieval. Evaluated on the Massive Multilingual Text Embedding Benchmark (MMTEB), which includes over one hundred tasks across 250+ languages, Gemini Embedding substantially outperforms prior state-of-the-art models, demonstrating considerable improvements in embedding quality. Achieving state-of-the-art performance across MMTEB's multilingual, English, and code benchmarks, our unified model demonstrates strong capabilities across a broad selection of tasks and surpasses specialized domain-specific models. Show less

publications.title: Book: The Kubernetes Workshop
publications.description: From building your own cluster to running cloud-native applications with Kubernetes, this workshop covers it all using engaging examples and activities. Thanks to its extensive support for managing hundreds of containers that run cloud-native applications, Kubernetes is the most popular open source container orchestration platform that makes cluster management easy. This workshop adopts a practical approach to get you acquainted with the Kubernetes environment and its applications. Starting with an introduction to the fundamentals of Kubernetes, you'll install and set up your Kubernetes environment. You'll understand how to write YAML files and deploy your first simple web application container using Pod. You'll then assign human-friendly names to Pods, explore various Kubernetes entities and functions, and discover when to use them. As you work through the chapters, this Kubernetes book will show you how you can make full-scale use of Kubernetes by applying a variety of techniques for designing components and deploying clusters. You'll also get to grips with security policies for limiting access to certain functions inside the cluster. Toward the end of the book, you'll get a rundown of Kubernetes advanced features for building your own controller and upgrading to a Kubernetes cluster without downtime. By the end of this workshop, you'll be able to manage containers and run cloud-based applications efficiently using Kubernetes. Show less

publications.title: EmbeddingGemma: Powerful and Lightweight Text Representations
publications.description: We introduce EmbeddingGemma, a new lightweight, open text embedding model based on the Gemma 3 language model family. Our innovative training recipe strategically captures knowledge from larger models via encoder-decoder initialization and geometric embedding distillation. We improve model robustness and expressiveness with a spread-out regularizer, and ensure generalizability by merging checkpoints from varied, optimized mixtures. Evaluated on the Massive Text Embedding Benchmark (MTEB) across multilingual, English, and code domains, EmbeddingGemma (300M) achieves state-of-the-art results. Notably, it outperforms prior top models, both proprietary and open, with fewer than 500M parameters, and provides performance comparable to models double its size, offering an exceptional performance-to-cost ratio. Remarkably, this lead persists when quantizing model weights or truncating embedding outputs. This makes EmbeddingGemma particularly well-suited for low-latency and high-throughput use cases such as on-device applications. We provide ablation studies exploring our key design choices. We release EmbeddingGemma to the community to promote further research. Show less

publications.title: Entity Image and Mixed-Modal Image Retrieval Datasets
publications.description: Despite advances in multimodal learning, challenging benchmarks for mixed-modal image retrieval that combines visual and textual information are lacking. This paper introduces a novel benchmark to rigorously evaluate image retrieval that demands deep cross-modal contextual understanding. We present two new datasets: the Entity Image Dataset (EI), providing canonical images for Wikipedia entities, and the Mixed-Modal Image Retrieval Dataset (MMIR), derived from the WIT dataset. The MMIR benchmark features two challenging query types requiring models to ground textual descriptions in the context of provided visual entities: single entity-image queries (one entity image with descriptive text) and multi-entity-image queries (multiple entity images with relational text). We empirically validate the benchmark's utility as both a training corpus and an evaluation set for mixed-modal retrieval. The quality of both datasets is further affirmed through crowd-sourced human annotations. Show less

publications.title: Gemini Embedding: Generalizable Embeddings from Gemini
publications.description: In this report, we introduce Gemini Embedding, a state-of-the-art embedding model leveraging the power of Gemini, Google's most capable large language model. Capitalizing on Gemini's inherent multilingual and code understanding capabilities, Gemini Embedding produces highly generalizable embeddings for text spanning numerous languages and textual modalities. The representations generated by Gemini Embedding can be precomputed and applied to a variety of downstream tasks including classification, similarity, clustering, ranking, and retrieval. Evaluated on the Massive Multilingual Text Embedding Benchmark (MMTEB), which includes over one hundred tasks across 250+ languages, Gemini Embedding substantially outperforms prior state-of-the-art models, demonstrating considerable improvements in embedding quality. Achieving state-of-the-art performance across MMTEB's multilingual, English, and code benchmarks, our unified model demonstrates strong capabilities across a broad selection of tasks and surpasses specialized domain-specific models. Show less

publications.title: Book: The Kubernetes Workshop
publications.description: From building your own cluster to running cloud-native applications with Kubernetes, this workshop covers it all using engaging examples and activities. Thanks to its extensive support for managing hundreds of containers that run cloud-native applications, Kubernetes is the most popular open source container orchestration platform that makes cluster management easy. This workshop adopts a practical approach to get you acquainted with the Kubernetes environment and its applications. Starting with an introduction to the fundamentals of Kubernetes, you'll install and set up your Kubernetes environment. You'll understand how to write YAML files and deploy your first simple web application container using Pod. You'll then assign human-friendly names to Pods, explore various Kubernetes entities and functions, and discover when to use them. As you work through the chapters, this Kubernetes book will show you how you can make full-scale use of Kubernetes by applying a variety of techniques for designing components and deploying clusters. You'll also get to grips with security policies for limiting access to certain functions inside the cluster. Toward the end of the book, you'll get a rundown of Kubernetes advanced features for building your own controller and upgrading to a Kubernetes cluster without downtime. By the end of this workshop, you'll be able to manage containers and run cloud-based applications efficiently using Kubernetes. Show less

education.description: Thesis: "Single Agent’s Adventures in Google Football Environment by means of Reinforcement Learning" Abstract: “The Google Research Football paper presents benchmark training results. The best of them are obtained using a graphical observation in the form of a 2D mini-map representing the football pitch. Our work aimed to test the possibility of using alternative observations. These are floating‐point vectors featuring, among others, the absolute positions of the players and the ball. We developed various training techniques and enhancements that allowed us to reach a high position at the public leaderboard. In particular, we have managed to win against all Google Brain agents. publications.title: PromptWizard: Task-Aware Agent-driven Prompt Optimization Framework
publications.description: Output of LLM can be significantly improved by leving prompt engineering. However, manual prompt engineering is labor-intensive and domain-specific, necessitating automated solutions. This paper introduces PromptWizard, a novel framework leveraging LLMs to iteratively synthesize and refine prompts tailored to specific tasks. Unlike existing approaches, PromptWizard optimizes both prompt instructions and in-context examples, maximizing model performance. The framework iteratively refines prompts by mutating instructions and incorporating negative examples to deepen understanding and ensure diversity. It further enhances both instructions and examples with the aid of a critic, synthesizing new instructions and examples enriched with detailed reasoning steps for optimal performance. Show less

publications.title: Fast Convergence to Near Optimal Solution for Job Shop Scheduling using Cat Swarm Optimization
publications.description: Job Shop Scheduling problem has wide range of applications. However it being a NP-Hard optimization problem, always ﬁnding an optimal solution is not possible in polynomial amount of time. In this paper we propose a heuristic approach to ﬁnd near optimal solution for Job Shop Scheduling Problem in predetermined amount of time using Cat Swarm Optimization. Novelty in our approach is our non-conventional way of representing position of cat in search space that ensures advantage of spatial locality is taken. Further while exploring the search space using randomization, we never explore an infeasible solution. This reduces search time. Our proposed approach outperforms some of the conventional algorithms and achieves nearly 86% accuracy, while restricting processing time to one second. Show less

projects.description: Predict set of customers who would get churned in next month from the premium subscription. This was intended to help the marketing team to initiate targeted marketing campaign in order to retain user base. Mentored an intern for this project.

projects.name: Enabling Automatic Movie Scene Understanding
projects.description: In this project we try to make system understand the semantics in a video and across videos. To achieve this we make use of several deep learning models. System tries to recognize actions, detect objects, tell whether a person is speaking or is listening,  nd emotions, age and other attributes of person. We form a semantic network out of such knowledge gained from video and query this network/graph to answer several types of questions asked by end user. Input to the system is a set of videos and their subtitle  les, output is a summary and a semantic network which is build over the information gained from video. Further this system would be also useful in searching for content over a set videos. Show less

projects.name: Semantic Approach for Domain Specific Search Engine
projects.description: Designed a search engine for a vertical domain, which can understand semantics related to that domain.

projects.name: Unsupervised way of learning Predicates using Semantic Web, PCFG AND WWW
projects.description: A model is developed to predict the intent when given a sentence. ADA Boost and J48 algorithms were used. With the help of semantic web, probabilistic context free grammar and exploring the search results of a search engine, we build training dataset.

projects.name: Arithmetic word Problem Solver (using ML in pre-LLM era)
projects.description: Make system learn how to solve arithmetic word problems. Question given to system would be something like "Ram has 2 red balls and 3 blue balls. He gave 1 blue ball to Shyam. How many red balls does Shyam have ?" System should understand sentences and form mathematical equations by identifying variables and their values. A separate Machine learning model was trained to identify containers, classify verbs, decide which math operation to perform, identify entities and its adjectives.

This accompanied with a desktop application to synchronize data on cloud storage account with its copy on desktop.Designed algorithm for collaborative text editor.

projects.name: Patient's Communicator
projects.description: Software application made using Java Applets along with a dedicated hardware for patient's to access, in order to communicate effectively.This project is for those who are in ICU, suffering from parkinsons, suffering from tamering of hand and can't speak.

publications.title: PromptWizard: Task-Aware Agent-driven Prompt Optimization Framework
publications.description: Output of LLM can be significantly improved by leving prompt engineering. However, manual prompt engineering is labor-intensive and domain-specific, necessitating automated solutions. This paper introduces PromptWizard, a novel framework leveraging LLMs to iteratively synthesize and refine prompts tailored to specific tasks. Unlike existing approaches, PromptWizard optimizes both prompt instructions and in-context examples, maximizing model performance. The framework iteratively refines prompts by mutating instructions and incorporating negative examples to deepen understanding and ensure diversity. It further enhances both instructions and examples with the aid of a critic, synthesizing new instructions and examples enriched with detailed reasoning steps for optimal performance. Show less

publications.title: Fast Convergence to Near Optimal Solution for Job Shop Scheduling using Cat Swarm Optimization
publications.description: Job Shop Scheduling problem has wide range of applications. However it being a NP-Hard optimization problem, always ﬁnding an optimal solution is not possible in polynomial amount of time. In this paper we propose a heuristic approach to ﬁnd near optimal solution for Job Shop Scheduling Problem in predetermined amount of time using Cat Swarm Optimization. Novelty in our approach is our non-conventional way of representing position of cat in search space that ensures advantage of spatial locality is taken. Further while exploring the search space using randomization, we never explore an infeasible solution. This reduces search time. Our proposed approach outperforms some of the conventional algorithms and achieves nearly 86% accuracy, while restricting processing time to one second. Show less

name: Michael J.
title: AI Research Scientist @Anthropic | Former Senior ML Engineer @IBM | 20+ yrs in NLP, LLM Alignment, Speech & Applied AI
about: I am an AI research scientist with over 20 years of cross-disciplinary R&D experience in speech recognition, natural language processing (NLP), and large-scale language models (LLMs). I began my career at Peking University with a degree in Information Science. I then pursued a Master's degree in Computer Science at the University of Southern California (USC), focusing on speech recognition and statistical machine learning. I also worked on early speech modeling projects at SRI International, participating in the development of speech recognition prototypes for human-computer interaction systems. I joined IBM's New York Lab in 2006 and have held positions as a data mining engineer, machine learning engineer, and research engineer, focusing on applying NLP and ML systems to industry-wide scenarios such as intelligent customer service, semantic search, and financial risk management. During this time, I led multiple end-to-end AI projects, becoming proficient in model development and deployment using platforms such as TensorFlow, PyTorch, and Spark. I also facilitated the patenting and transformation of numerous research findings into enterprise solutions. Since 2021, I have joined Anthropic, where I have been involved in the design of key modules for large-scale language models (the Claude series), focusing on alignment, security, and conversational capabilities, particularly within subsystems such as RLHF, Constitutional AI, and long-context understanding. I built an experimental framework for the RLHF reward model, designed a multi-dimensional user preference scoring system, and assisted enterprise clients (in finance, law, education, and other sectors) with private model deployment and fine-tuning. During this work, I collaborated closely with multiple teams, including product, security, and legal, to ensure model compliance, security, and controllability. I also actively participated in research initiatives on AI ethics and system security, publishing relevant results at top international conferences such as NeurIPS and ICLR, and was invited to present at the Stanford AI Symposium. I believe that AI is not only an engineering challenge but also a social responsibility. The boundaries of technology must be stretched in tandem with human values. I welcome discussions and collaborations with you.
current_description: I joined Anthropic in 2021 and focus on optimizing the alignment, controllability, and multi-round contextual reasoning capabilities of large models. I participated in the entire process from model training to product implementation, balancing academic research and engineering applications. I participated in the design and experimentation of Constitutional AI methods, exploring rule-based approaches to improve the behavioral consistency and value security of LLMs. My findings were incorporated into the core training process of the Claude series of models and summarized and published in an internal whitepaper. I built an experimental framework for training the RLHF reward model, designed prompts and a multi-dimensional preference scoring system, and improved the naturalness and stability of the model in real-world conversational tasks. I designed private deployment and fine-tuning solutions for the Claude API for large enterprise clients (including those in finance, law, and education). I assisted the team in developing long-context processing mechanisms, increasing the context length support to over 100,000 tokens. I collaborated with multiple departments, including product, security, and legal, to ensure that model implementation complied with regulatory and ethical requirements. I also mentored several doctoral interns and research engineers, establishing standard research processes and a shared knowledge base. He has participated in publishing many results at top conferences such as NeurIPS, ICLR, and ACL, and was invited to share research progress on alignment and AI security design at the Stanford University AI Seminar. Show less

Research in concurrency bug detection using language model. I contributed towards developing and publishing a code-trained LM to spot concurrency errors in GO routines.

Research in online RL for program synthesizers. Developed the first RL-based bidirectional LM for synthetic compiler benchmarks. Our effort led to 2 publications and contributions to CompilerGym, a tool for RL over code.

name: Boyuan Chen
title: Research Scientist at OpenAI
about: I'm Boyuan Chen (陈博远), a research scientist at OpenAI. I am one of the five researchers training GPT image generation and also a member of the Sora video generation team. I earned my PhD in EECS from MIT, with a minor in philosophy. My research centers on world models, embodied AI, and reinforcement learning—combining them to make AI systems more capable of understanding and acting in the physical world. I have authored several papers recognized in both industry and academia, including Diffusion Forcing, SpatialVLM, and History Guidance.
current_description: GPT image generation. Member of the 5-person core research team who trains the model. Also member of the Sora video generation team. Work on Reinforcement Learning and World Models.

experience_summary.description: GPT image generation. Member of the 5-person core research team who trains the model. Also member of the Sora video generation team. Work on Reinforcement Learning and World Models.
PhD student at MIT Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science (EECS). AI research on world models, reinforcement learning and robotics.
Lead the development of a 26B Multi-Modal Large Language Models SpatialVLM Optimized Google's LLM for spatial reasoning. LLM training, data generation, instruction tuning and visual alignment
Research how to ground Large Language Models with multimodal input; Prototyped a multimodal LLM for decision making in Google X's Everyday Robot Project.

Research in vision and reinforcement learning advised by Prof. Pieter Abbeel and Prof. Trevor Darrell. Propose, implement and test new ideas. Research focus is on robotic manipulation and representation learning.

I have authored several papers recognized in both industry and academia, including Diffusion Forcing, SpatialVLM, and History Guidance.
